required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intensity Modulated Radiotherapy for Breast Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy for Breast Cancer: A Phase I Feasibility Study

brief_summary.textblock: This study delivers radiation therapy to any residual breast tissue and the chest wall plus lymph node areas around the breast. These lymph node areas are under the arm, around the collar bone, and under the sternum (breastbone).

detailed_description.textblock: IMRT treatment uses a computer-controlled x-ray (CT) to deliver radiation beams at several different angles and strengths to deliver precise doses to the regions at risk for recurrence of breast cancer while reducing or sparing the dose to critical structures (heart, lungs) and nearby normal tissue.

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the feasibility of adjuvant comprehensive radiation therapy via IMRT with daily set-up position verified using 3D verification
primary_outcome.description: The study will be deemed infeasible if greater than 10% of enrolled patients have at least one of the following outcomes: Patient cannot be given the treatment because her anatomy is such that a dosimetrically satisfactory treatment plan cannot be devised for her. Within 1 year of protocol registration, the patient develops radiation pneumonitis toxicity of greater than or equal to grade 3 by CTCAE scales. Within 1 year of protocol registration, the patient develops any local or regional breast cancer recurrence. Within 1 year of protocol registration, the patient dies from causes judged to be related to her treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the rate and severity of both acute and late cutaneous toxicity
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6-8 months following completion of treatment and 12-14 months following completion of treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the rate and severity of late subcutaneous fibrosis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6-8 months following completion of treatment and 12-14 months following completion of treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate the rate of radiation pneumonitis
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6-8 weeks following completion of treatment, 3-4 months following completion of treatment, 6-8 months following completion of treatment, and 12-14 months following completion of treatment
Pretreatment and 3-4 months following completion of treatment
secondary_outcome.description: For patients who receive physical therapy, objective measures of the rotator cuff, bursa, and joint space will be evaluated by diagnostic ultrasound if medically indicated.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Pretreatment, 6-8 months following completion of treatment, and 12-14 months following completion of treatment
12-14 months following completion of radiation therapy

secondary_outcome.measure: Evaluate patient set-up reproducibility in breast cancer patients treated with IMRT using daily 3D position verification

arm_group.description: The prescribed dose for all patients will be 5040 cGy in 28 fractions. Patients will receive external beam treatment once a day, five days a week for approximately five and a half weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female gender
- Age ≥ 18 years
- Invasive primary female breast cancer
- Pathologically proven regional nodal metastasis
- Status post mastectomy or partial mastectomy with an assessment of axillary nodes via sentinel lymph node biopsy and/or axillary lymph node dissection.
- Signed study specific consent form
Exclusion Criteria:
- Distant metastasis
- Currently Pregnant
- Psychiatric or addictive disorders that preclude informed consent
- Time from initial diagnosis to the start of radiation therapy > one year
- Estimated life expectancy judged to be < one year
- Prior radiation to the ipsilateral breast or chest wall
- Primary breast cancer is lymphoma or sarcoma
- Patients being treated with concurrent chemotherapy.

link.description: Alvin J. Siteman Cancer Center at Barnes-Jewish Hospital and Washington University School of Medicine
